title: Dom Pedro V Theatre
text:
The Dom Pedro V Theatre (; ), is a historical theatre situated at "Largo de Santo Agostinho" in <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Louren%C3%A7o%2C%20Macau">São Lourenço</a>, <a href="Macau">Macau</a>, <a href="China">China</a>. It is one of the first western-style theatres in <a href="East%20Asia">East Asia</a>. The theater is an important landmark in the region and remains a venue for important public events and celebrations today.
History.
The theatre was built in 1860 by local Portuguese to commemorate their reigning <a href="king">king</a>, <a href="Peter%20V%20of%20Portugal">Peter V</a>. It used to be a regular meeting place for the Portuguese and Macanese people living in Macau. Its current façade was added in 1873. The theater was used as a refugee shelter in the <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. In 2005, the theater became one of the designated sites of the <a href="Historic%20Centre%20of%20Macau">Historic Centre of Macau</a> enlisted on the <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="World%20Heritage%20List">World Heritage List</a>. In August 2017, the portico ceiling of the theater was damaged due to <a href="Typhoon%20Hato">Typhoon Hato</a>.
Architecture.
The theater is neo-classical in design, incorporating a portico front on a rectilinear plan. The building is 41.5 metres long and 22 metres wide. Apart from being a theatre, it features a ballroom, a study room, and a billiard room.
